question: So, you never heard of him.
answer: Nope.

question: Do you know who Arturo Toscanini is?
answer: Sure.

question: He's as big as Toscanini, maybe even bigger. In this neck of the woods, he's probably Bob Hope and Betty Grable rolled into one.
answer: Jeez, and I never heard of him.

question: You were in insurance before the war.
answer: Right. Claims assessor.

question: Conscientious, determined, dogged.
answer: They said I was dogged?

question: Well, they say here that when you went on a case, you stayed on it. Now we can't take every Nazi in this country to trial, although I would like to; it's an impossibility. So we're going for the big boys in industry, education, law, culture.
answer: Like this bandleader.

question: You live here, in Berlin?
answer: Yes.

question: You do shorthand and typing?
answer: Yes.

question: Okay, let's see. How long were you in the camp for?
answer: Three months.

question: Says here because of your father. What's that mean?
answer: My father was one of the officers in the plot against Hitler. They arrested the plotters and their families.

question: Your mother, too.
answer: Yes. She suffered longer. She was in Ravensbruck.

question: And your father was executed. I'm gonna call you Emmi, you're gonna call me Steve. Okay? I got a list of stuff here I'd like you to get for me.
answer: Major...

question: Steve.
answer: There have been messages for you. A Lieutenant David Wills called from the Allied Kommandatura Cultural Affairs office in Wiesbaden. I don't know who he is. Then there have been three calls from Dr. Furtwngler wanting to know when you wish to see him. I did not speak to him personally...

question: Think you can get me any of that?
answer: Oh yes, Major, I have recordings of all his symphonies. I kept them safe during the bombing. My favourite is the Seventh Symphony.

question: Mine's the Eleventh.
answer: But... he only wrote nine, Major.

question: I'm kidding, Emmi. What about a record player? You have that, too?
answer: No. Ours was damaged.

question: What's in those files?
answer: The names of the members of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra since 1934 together with their questionnaires. Major, what am I to tell Dr. Furtwngler?

question: Yeah.
answer: Lieutenant Wills reporting to Major Arnold. Sir.

question: For Chrissakes I hate that shit, cut it out.
answer: I'm very sorry.

question: I'm Steve. What's your name?
answer: David. David Wills. I'm your liaison officer with the Allied Kommandatura Cultural Affairs Committee. Sir.

question: Sounds a lot of run. So they sent the big guns to check up on me. We recruiting children now?
answer: I guess so, sir.

question: You call me sir again and I'll make you listen to Beethoven. Where you from, David?
answer: was born here, in Leipzig. I escaped in '36. My parents, they sent me to my uncle in Philadelphia. They were to follow. But they delayed and... Our family name was Weill. But that doesn't sound well in English. My uncle changed it to Wills and...

question: Sit down, Werner. I want you to understand why you're here. This is an investigation into Wilhelm Furtwngler, former Prussian Privy Councillor, banned from public life under Control Council Directive No 24 and who's applied to come before the Tribunal of Artists of the Denazification Commission. I'm interested in what he was up to from 1933 to the end of the war, understood? Rudolf Otto Werner. Wind section since 1936. What instrument did you play?
answer: First oboe.

question: I have your questionnaire here. It says you were never a member of the Nazi Party.
answer: Absolutely not. No, I was never a Nazi, I have no interest in politics, I'm a musician -

question: Hey, hey, slow up, Fraulein Straube has to take down what you say.
answer: Straube? Any relation to Colonel Joachim Straube?

question: It's a great honour to meet you, Fraulein. Your father was a great patriot. Dr. Furtwngler is a great musician. He actively opposed the Nazis and later on he helped many Jews to escape.
answer: Then how do you explain him being made a Prussian Privy Councillor?

question: It was Hermann Goering. I was told he just made the maestro his Privy Councillor, no questions asked. Although Dr. Furtwngler stood up to him. And to Dr. Goebbels.
answer: He also conducted for Hitler, didn't he?

question: Yes, that's true, but he refused to give the Nazi salute. He kept his baton in his right hand. In Hitler's presence. That was a brave act...
answer: Brave? To celebrate Hitler's birthday with some heroic piece by Wagner but without the Nazi salute? Bravo.

question: It was Beethoven's Ninth.
answer: Do you really think it was brave? Didn't he bow to him and shake his hand?

question: No, no, no, I give you my word. I was never a member of the Nazi Party. Never. I am in the percussion section. I play the timpani. Anyway, they would never have allowed it. My brother was married to a Jewess, may she rest in peace. And Goebbels said... ...please take this down carefully, because it's most important, Fraulein?
answer: Straube.

question: Straube? Are you by any chance related to Colonel Joachim Straube?
answer: My father.

question: No, we...we played on the evening before the Rally.
answer: Oh! The evening before, I see...

question: Yes, Dr. Furtwngler was absolutely clear about this
answer: Politics and art must be kept separate. I'll remember that. But let me see if you can help me with something I just don't understand. I'd really like to know why all you guys are so crazy about him. What's his secret?

question: Well, it's hard to explain. I can only tell you from my own experience. Soon after I joined the orchestra, we were rehearsing the Third Symphony of Beethoven, the Eroica. There are several rather difficult passages for the timpani. One particular crescendo. During the break, I asked how he wanted it played. He was studying his score. He didn't look up. He said, 'Just watch me.' So, of course, I did. I never stopped watching him. The moment came. And suddenly, he turned to me and our eyes were locked. There was something in his look that... that simply demanded the crescendo. I shall never forget his look. It was a moment of... of magic.
answer: You ever seen Adolf Hitler's eyes when he was making a speech? I've seen 'em on films.

question: Yes.
answer: Was looking at Furtwngler like that?

question: I don't know what you mean, Major.
answer: When you got to the crescendo. You think a whole orchestra, what, a hundred and forty or so guys, could be orchestrated?

question: When you got to the crescendo. You think a whole orchestra, what, a hundred and forty or so guys, could be orchestrated?
answer: I guess it's possible.

question: So, what does the Russki want?
answer: Colonel Dymshitz asked specially to see you.

question: 'Dim-shits'? What the hell are they doing?
answer: They're trying to sort out some of the works of art the Nazis stole from occupied territories. Who really owns what? That's Colonel Dymshitz, on the far side.

question: I know who Georges Braque is, Captain. Hello, Major, my name is Dymshitz. I'm glad to see you.
answer: Colonel. Pleasure.

question: So, Major, tell me, have you questioned Dr. Furtwngler?
answer: Not yet.

question: I clicked my heels, saluted and bowed at the same time.
answer: That's because you had a proper upbringing.

question: That's right. I was raised very strictly. So don't speak before you are spoken to!
answer: Oh! And don't wave your hands about!

question: Respect your elders and your betters!
answer: And no elbows on the table!

question: Eating is eating... and...
answer: And talking is talking! Well, I think we better get on.

question: Right. So, this is going to be very formal, too, now. Lieutenant David Wills requests die pleasure of die company of Fraulein Emmi Straube at dinner any night she cares.
answer: David, need to ask you something. You heard this rumour the British found something called the Hinkel Archive?

question: Yes.
answer: So what is it?

question: The British occupy the building where this guy, Hinkel, ran the Nazi Ministry of Culture and it seems they've... they've discovered his secret archive.
answer: What's that mean?

question: I don't know, but the British are excited about it, I know that. The rumour is Hinkel kept a file on every artist working in the Third Reich.
answer: Jeez. And you think the British'll share it with their Allies?

question: Major Richards said he'd call to let us know.
answer: That's big of him. Okay, better question the next witness. I bet you a bottle of French champagne he tells us the baton story inside ten minutes.

question: Five minutes.
answer: It's a bet. You're the witness, Emmi. Helmuth Alfred Rode. Second violinist since 1935. What's it mean, second violinist?

question: It's a bet. You're the witness, Emmi. Helmuth Alfred Rode. Second violinist since 1935. What's it mean, second violinist?
answer: It means I wasn't good enough to be a first violinist.

question: Good, and according to your questionnaire, Helmuth, you never joined the Nazi Party.
answer: Me? Never. Never. I... I know everyone now says they were never Nazis but in my case it is absolutely one hundred per cent true. I am a Catholic, it would have been totally against my conscience. Is it true you're going to interview Dr. Furtwngler today?

question: I'll ask the questions, Helmuth.
answer: Excuse me. Did you know that he refused to give the Nazi salute when Hitler was present in the audience? The problem was how could he avoid giving the Devil's salute when Satan was actually sitting there. And, I said, 'Dr. Furtwngler, why not enter with the baton in your right hand? Hitler will be sitting in the front row. If you give the salute with the baton in your right hand it'll look like you're going to poke his eyes out.' He was...He was really grateful to me for that. After the concert, I... I stole that baton as a memento of a great act of courage. I still have it. I should have brought it to show you. I hope I'm not going too fast for you, Fraulein?-

question: Excuse me. Did you know that he refused to give the Nazi salute when Hitler was present in the audience? The problem was how could he avoid giving the Devil's salute when Satan was actually sitting there. And, I said, 'Dr. Furtwngler, why not enter with the baton in your right hand? Hitler will be sitting in the front row. If you give the salute with the baton in your right hand it'll look like you're going to poke his eyes out.' He was...He was really grateful to me for that. After the concert, I... I stole that baton as a memento of a great act of courage. I still have it. I should have brought it to show you. I hope I'm not going too fast for you, Fraulein?-
answer: Straube.

question: Straube. Any relation to Colonel Joachim Straube?
answer: My father.

question: Oh, we didn't play for his birthday, we played the evening before - it was the 19th of April not the 20th.
answer: Do you know Hans Hinkel?

question: Do I know Hans Hinkel?
answer: That's what I asked.

question: Do I know Hans Hinkel?
answer: You seem to understand the question, now how about answering it?

question: Hans Hinkel was in the Ministry of Culture; how could I know such a man? I I hear the British have his... his archive, files, records.
answer: Do you know what's in this archive?

question: How could I know what's in the archive?
answer: Okay, you can go now, Helmuth. Get out.

question: I'm very sorry, Major, but I promised her mother, we have to go.
answer: Don't see me to my door, there's no need.

question: But I promised your mother.
answer: Well, sleep well. Excuse me, Major. I found this on Helmuth Rode. You remember? The second violinist? Look, he's Austrian not German. But it's this that's more important, I think...

question: Major.
answer: Helmuth.

question: Guess what I am holding in my hand. You like guessing games?
answer: Love 'em, Helmuth. I give up. What are you holding in your hand?

question: It's Dr. Furtwngler's baton, which I stole.
answer: The one he kept in his right hand. Yes, you remember.

question: Yes, you remember.
answer: How could I forget? Show me.

question: Show you?
answer: Yeah, show me, I want to see you do it. Pretend I'm Adolf. You're the maestro, and you have the baton in your right hand, but you give me the salute just the same.

question: Not here, Major, there are people, if anybody should see... please, please, Major...
answer: Do it, Helmuth. Do it right. And I see what you mean. You nearly poked my eyes out.

question: Exactly. Replaces the baton, gives Steve the case.
answer: Don't worry, Helmuth, it'll be our secret. Great catch, kid. The boy runs off.

question: So. You wanted to see me. You usually don't work on Sunday, Major?
answer: All in the cause of humanity, Helmuth. Or should I call you one- zero-four-nine-three-three-one?

question: What?
answer: One-zero-four-nine-three-three- one. Or d'you mind if I just call you 'one'? You know what I say you are, Helmuth? I say you're a piece of shit.

question: That bastard!
answer: Who's the bastard, Helmuth? Hinkel? Why? He promised to remove your file? And what about before that? What were you a member of in Austria? Was a member of...? Speak up?

question: I was a member of the Communist Party. I was a communist. That's what Hinkel had over me. He knew everything. He held that over me. That's how he made me co-operate.
answer: Oh, I see, he made you co-operate. And now are you a communist again?

question: You don't know what it's like to wake up every single morning of your life terrified, you don't know that - I would never, in my wildest dreams, have ever been a second violinist in the Berlin Philharmonic. When they got rid of the... the Jews in the orchestra, it gave people like me a chance.
answer: Helmuth, you ever heard of plea- bargaining? Talk about power, I have the power to give you work, make your life easier. Your past won't be mentioned. I could give you a job tomorrow but I have to get something in return. See, Helmuth? That's plea-bargaining. I can give you freedom of movement, freedom to work, freedom, Helmuth. But I need something in return.

question: Major, we're discussing a man of genius, I don't want...
answer: Fuck that, Helmuth. You want to discuss symbols here? This guy was a front man. He was the piper, but he played their tune, you get my philosophical meaning? I'm not interested in small fish, I'm after Moby Dick. Come on, Helmuth. Hard facts.

question: The only thing I know is he's an anti-Semite.
answer: Of course. You, too. Like everyone else in this goddamn country.

question: I've remembered something else...
answer: Yeah?

question: Furtwngler sent Hitler a telegram for his birthday.
answer: He did?

question: One of your people told me.
answer: One of my people?

question: Yes. A corporal. US Army. A Jew. He said he'd seen the telegram in the Chancellery.
answer: Son-of-a-gun. We'll find the corporal and we'll find the telegram. But I need documentary proof. You know of anything like that?

question: No. But that's why we hated him. We admired him as a conductor but we all hated him too because he didn't have to join the Party and yet he had a better life than any of us. He didn't have to go and deliver a report after every trip abroad. He got everything from them, everything. He was filthier than any of us Party members. There's a rumour... I don't know if it's true or not... but ask him about von der Null.
answer: Never heard of him, who is he?

question: Edwin von der Null. Music critic. He gave Furtwngler terrible reviews while he raved about Herbert von Karajan.
answer: Who's he?

question: Also a conductor. Very brilliant. Young. Von der Null called him 'The Miracle von Karajan'. Furtwngler was outraged and they say he had von der Null conscripted into the army. The same thing happened to another critic. True or not, it's not such a bad idea. Critics give you bad reviews, you have them sent to the Russian front. But if you really want to get Furtwngler, ask him about Herbert von Karajan.
answer: The Miracle Kid.

question: Yes, yes you may notice that he cannot even bring himself to utter his name, he... he refers to him as K. And ask him about his private life.
answer: His private life?

question: Where do you stand on all this?
answer: On all what?

question: On Furtwngler.
answer: I don't know.

question: You represent the United States now. We have a moral duty to be just and we have to be seen to be just.
answer: Major Arnold believes he has a moral duty, too.

question: To co-operation.
answer: I was in Vienna. I had with me an Austrian chauffeur, Max his name was, he spent time in the camps. We were looking at these Viennese cleaning up the bomb damage, scavenging for rotting food, butt ends, anything. I said, 'To think a million of these people came out to welcome Adolf on the day he entered the city, a million of 'em, and now look at 'em.' And Max said, 'Oh, not these people, Major. These people were all at home hiding Jews in their attics.' You get the point, Colonel? The point is they're all full of shit.

question: Furtwngler's in a different category.
answer: We're dealing with degenerates here.

question: Degenerates? A great artist will have great privileges in a Russian zone.
answer: That's why he didn't get the hell out of here when he had the chance! I put that to him, he couldn't answer. Why didn't he go and direct in America, like that Italian, Toscanini.

question: Perhaps... perhaps he believed he could at least try to preserve something important, things like an orchestra, a school. That's his country. Maybe he has an old mother who can't be left alone. Maybe he has brothers, sisters... you can't...
answer: Colonel. He had no sisters, no brothers, only a lot of love affairs.

question: Anyway, Major, why should he leave his country, his mother tongue, his family, his history, his past, his future, just because now, suddenly, there is a dictatorship? Why?
answer: But what... before that turns rotten... What if they surround the space with barbed wire, Colonel?

question: Don't talk about things you know nothing about. He was in a dictatorship!
answer: Yeah, yeah, art and politics, yeah, yeah, I heard all about that.

question: In a dictatorship, art belongs to the Party. If you want to be a conductor, you have to have an orchestra. And you can only get an orchestra if you have contact with the power. All over the world you need the right contacts and you have to make the right compromises.
answer: This is what I'm saying. He must have had Party contacts.

question: There are good Party members who help, and there are dirty non-Party members who inform on you. Of course, they gave him privileges. And suddenly, Steve, suddenly you notice that they like you. They honour you, suddenly you are the director of the best museum in the world, for example.
answer: What museum?

question: I'm sorry. Museum? Not... I said orchestra. Sorry. Believe me. Help me, Steve. You say you answer for someone from high up. I, too, have orders from high up. Very high up. We want Furtwngler. I'll give you in return the whole orchestra, four, five conductors. I need him, Steve.
answer: No can do.

question: Let Furtwngler go. Please.
answer: I have a duty.

question: Duty? I am sorry, duty? Duty fucking duty. Trouble is, you Americans want everybody to live like you. We liberated Berlin, Major Steve, not you. Our duty also is to bring back the best of German culture.
answer: I'm gonna get that fucking bandleader, Colonel. No deal. No fucking deal.

question: Dr. Furtwngler! Come in, come in, sit down. No, no, take this one, it's more comfortable If it's too hot, open your tie. Go ahead, be my guest. And what was that? Gee, that's a thing of beauty, honest to God, a real thing of beauty. I'm going to try to remember that. Liberty, humanity and justice. Beautiful. But you used the word 'naive'. Are you now saying you think you were wrong? That art and politics can't be separated? And when did you first learn that - when you sent the telegram? Was that the surrender signal, the waving of the white flag? 'Happy birthday, dear Adolf, love Wilhelm.' Or words to that effect. That sounds to me like you were dropping on your knees and saying, 'Okay, Adolf, you win. You're the number one man. Have a swell party.' The birthday greetings you sent to your old pal, Adolf Hider. Think carefully, Wilhelm... maybe not in your own name, but as Privy Councillor or Vice-President. Yes, David?
answer: Why not show Dr. Furtwngler the evidence. It may refresh his memory?

question: Well, I tried, you got to admit I tried. I thought I might just trap you there, Wilhelm, but David here was too quick for me. Smart move, David, smart move. No, I don't have the telegram, but I know it exists. And I want you to know, Wilhelm, we're going to keep looking for it because I believe you sent it. Art and politics, yeah, art and politics. Let's look at that. You and the Berlin Philharmonic toured the Third Reich, played in countries the Nazis had conquered. Are you saying that conducting in occupied territories from 1939 on wasn't a commercial for Adolf and all he stood for? You know something? You should've written our insurance policies for us because you got more exclusion clauses than Double Indemnity. What do you imagine people thought? The Berlin Philharmonic's taken over by Doctor Goebbels and his Propaganda Ministry but Wilhelm is a freelance, so art and politics are now entirely separate? Is that what you believed ordinary people thought? No! Tell me about von der Null. Yes, von der Null. How long's this going to go on, Wilhelm? I say von der Null, you say von der Null, I say von der Null, you say von der Null, we could go on all day. You know who von der Null is, don't you? Edwin von der Nuell, music critic. Isn't it true that because he gave you bad reviews and praised this young guy, Von Karajan, called him a goddamn miracle, said he was a better conductor than you, then you had von der Null conscripted into the army and no one's heard from him since? You sure you didn't call one of your close buddies and say, God in heaven, did you see what that guy von der Null wrote about me? The greatest conductor on earth. I want him out the way. He had the nerve to accuse me I am not playing enough modern music. Send him to Stalingrad. Isn't that what you did? You don't like criticism, do you, Wilhelm? You surely didn't like them saying there was another conductor who was better than you... Are you saying the name von der Null was never mentioned in your talks with Goebbels? And what did he say? And what happened to Von der Nul? You've really no idea? I'll tell you what happened. He died in Stalingrad. Now, that young conductor what's his name? That miracle kid, you know who I mean. Von Karajan! But you called him something else. C'mon. What did you call von Karajan? Say it. I'll say it, then. 'Little K.' Is that right? You couldn't even bear to say his name! I'll tell you why. You remember we talked about you playing for Hitler's birthday? And you told me that Goebbels got to your doctors first, that you were tricked? I have a different story to tell. I don't think you were tricked. Not in the way you describe. I believe something else happened. I've seen the Hinkel Archive, I've seen records of phone calls, and putting it all together, this is what I think happened. I think Goebbels said, 'Wilhelm, if you won't conduct for Adolf's birthday, we'll get the Miracle Kid, the guy that critic, von der Null, thinks is the greatest conductor in the world. He's not just willing to conduct for Adolf, he's offered to sing "Happy Birthday" as a solo.' Come on, admit it. K worried you, didn't he? He always worried you. In 1942, he's thirty-four years old, you're already fifty-six. And Goebbels and Goering keep saying to you, 'If you don't do it, little K will.' Never mind art and politics and symbols and airy-fairy bullshit about liberty, humanity and justice because I don't care how great you are. It's the oldest story in the book, The ageing Romeo jealous of the young buck. The real reason you didn't leave the country when you knew you should have was that you were frightened that, once you were out of the way, you'd be supplanted by the Miracle Kid, the Party's boy twice over, flashy, talented little K. Well, I'm just beginning to develop my theme. Isn't that what you call it in classical music, developing your theme? Okay, so they played on your insecurity. That's human, understandable. But, there is one guy who doesn't like little K as much as he likes you - yeah, the number one man your old pal, Adolf. He thinks you're the greatest, and when he says, I want Wilhelm for my birthday, boy, they better go out get Wilhelm. So, Josef calls and threatens you with little K. And you said to hell with the Ninth in Vienna, I'll give it to Adolf as a birthday present in Berlin. That's the trick they played, they got you by the balls and they squeezed. Hard. Why did you stay? Why did you play for them? Why were you the flag-carrier for their regime? Jealousy? You see, Wilhelm, I'm talking about ordinary, everyday reasons. Which is why I want to discuss your private life. How many illegitimate children do you have?
answer: Major, I don't see how this line of questioning could...

question: David, what are you Counsel for the Defence now? Did you hear the question? What? You like the women, don't you, Wilhelm? Isn't it true that before every concert you got a woman in your dressing room and gave her the old conductor's baton, isn't that true?
answer: Major, this is deeply offensive and repugnant!

question: You bet.
answer: and totally irrelevant.

question: Not so, Counsellor. That secretary of yours, she wasn't just your secretary, she procured women for you, didn't she? As many and as often as you wanted. No, I'm not going to stop it. Hitler himself offered you a beautiful house and a personal bomb shelter. But you see what I'm getting at? You get a gorgeous house, you're highly paid. What are you gonna do, stay or leave? One voice comes back at me
answer: Major, that's not a good argument. If Dr. Furtwngler did indeed enjoy all these... these privileges, he enjoyed them because of who he is and what he is. That's true of any leading artist in any country in the world.

question: But it still doesn't make them saints. They still have to get up and piss in the middle of the night, don't they? They can still be vindictive and envious and mean just like you and me. Well, just like me. Can't they? Okay, Wilhelm, go home now. Go home and think about these past twelve years. No, that's your problem, Wilhelm. You understand nothing. We'll call you. Go!
answer: Major.

question: What?
answer: Your manner.

question: My manner? Why don't you go downstairs, get a cup of coffee and calm down? What's the matter, Emmi? What's going on with you? What's wrong?
answer: I'm sorry but I have to leave. I'll find other work. You'll have to get someone else, that's all.

question: What is this, Emmi?
answer: I can't do this. It's not right.

question: What's not right?
answer: I have been questioned by the Gestapo just like that. Just like you questioned him.

question: Emmi, stop! I want to show you something. Let me show you something and then if you want to leave, you can leave, please please. His friends, they did this. And he gave them birthday concerts.
answer: But he had no idea, a lot of people had no idea. I only realised what was really going on when I got arrested.

question: If he had no idea, why did the Jews need saving? This is the question, Emmi, to all Germans
answer: I would like to go now, please.

question: Can I ask you a favour, Major?
answer: Yeah.

question: When you question him again, could you treat him with more respect?
answer: With more what? More what?

question: Major, he may just be the greatest conductor of this century and that merits respect.
answer: David, I don't understand a thing about you. You're a Jew. Are you a Jew?

question: Yes, I'm a Jew. But I like to think first I'm a human being.
answer: A human being, oh, good, I'm relieved, I thought you were going to say you were a music lover. This man, this great artist has made anti-Semitic remarks like you wouldn't believe. I got letters.

question: Major, show me someone who hasn't made an anti-Semitic remark and I'll show you the gates of paradise.
answer: What is it with you, David? Where are your feelings? Where's your hatred, your disgust? Where's your fucking outrage, David? Think of your parents, David, and then think of him conducting 'Happy Birthday, dear Adolf'. I mean, for Chrissake, whose side are you on? Grow up! Just grow the fuck up!
